por.por_cntn:
Whatcom Community College (WCC) is building the cybersecurity workforce in the Northwest through the successful completion of the NSF-funded Capacity Building in Cybersecurity grant. This project’s primary goal was to develop and implement two new degrees in cybersecurity – one at Whatcom Community College and one at Western Washington University (WWU) – with a seamless transfer pathway between the two. The project addressed a critical local and national issue: the tremendous demand for trained cybersecurity professionals. The implementation of the two degrees is helping to meet that need. In addition, the pathway to the WWU degree includes the transfer of applied credits into the major, which has not been available to Washington community college students prior to this project.

Along with these two new degrees, Whatcom also established articulation agreements with Bellingham Technical College to assure transferability of credits and developed courses for a state-approved Bachelors of Applied Science in IT Networking.

This project also included work with the University of Washington (UW) to develop an agreement that would enable students to transfer cybersecurity courses between UW’s three campuses. Work was also done to establish a pathway for Whatcom cybersecurity students into the University of Washington (still under development).

Students who wish to pursue cybersecurity careers and remain in the Northwest now have many educational options, and the area as a whole has been strengthened economically now that employers have a well-prepared workforce upon which to draw.

 


Last Modified: 09/22/2016
Modified by: Corrinne Sande
